History of Present Illness (HPI): The patient has been practicing muscle relaxation techniques which have helped them feel more relaxed and fall asleep faster. They have also engaged in writing about their feelings, particularly regarding an audition, which they found cathartic. The patient recognizes their tendency to be hard on themselves and feels pressure to succeed, which is exhausting. They are contemplating ways to enjoy music without the stress of performance, such as singing for fun, and are considering reaching out to their family to share their feelings
Psychosocial History: The patient feels distant from their family and attributes this to the pressure they are experiencing. They express concern about burdening their family with their problems but are open to the idea of reaching out to them
Physiological Observations: The patient reported feeling relaxed after practicing muscle relaxation techniques, which contributed to improved sleep quality
Progress Evaluation: The patient is making meaningful progress by implementing relaxation techniques and engaging in self-reflection through writing. They are also considering healthy steps to reconnect with their family
Therapeutic Interventions: The patient will continue practicing relaxation techniques and writing about their feelings. They plan to reach out to their family to share their feelings and will try to sing for fun without performance pressure
Next Steps: The patient aims to set aside time this weekend to sing for enjoyment and to reach out to their family this week
